description: Change of use from retail (Class A1) to restaurant/cafe (Class A3).
decision_conditions: The development to which this decision relates must begin within a period of 3 years starting with the prior approval date.Reason: This is required by paragraph C.2(3) of Part 3 of Schedule 2 to the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 (as amended).

The cumulative rating level of the noise from the kitchen extract system and other plant hereby permitted shall be at least 5dBA lower than the existing background noise level at any given time of operation. The noise levels shall be measured or predicted 1m externally to any window at the nearest residential facade. Measurements and assessment shall be made according to British Standard 4142:2014.Reason: To ensure satisfactory living conditions for neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

The development to which this decision relates shall not commence until full details, with calculations, of the proposed extraction system have been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. The submission shall include, where applicable, details of:i. The extract fan, silencers, anti-vibration mounts, high velocity cowl, filters, odour abatement and any other items of plant;ii. The velocity of the air at final discharge and duct termination height and locationiii. The retention time of gases in the carbon filters (where applicable);iv. A maintenance schedule;Before commencement of the approved ground floor use, the approved extraction system shall be installed on site in accordance with the approved details and shall be retained and maintained thereafter. Any variations thereafter shall be agreed in writing by the Local Planning Authority.Reason: These details are required prior to commencement of development because the details would affect the subsequent design of other elements of the scheme and must be agreed at the outset and to ensure satisfactory living conditions for neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to commencement of the development to which this decision relates the applicant shall provide a scheme to the Local Planning Authority for its written approval detailing sound transmission reduction measures to be installed within the ceiling for the proposed A3 use. The scheme shall be designed to be 5dB better than that given in Approved Document E (2003 Edition incorporating 2004 and 2010 amendments) of the Building Regulations (Table 0.1a, page 12). Once agreed in writing by the Local Planning Authority, the approved details shall be installed prior to the development being occupied and retained thereafter.Reason: These details are required prior to commencement of development because the details would affect the subsequent design of other elements of the scheme and must be agreed at the outset and to ensure satisfactory living conditions for neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

The cafe use to which this decision relates shall not open outside of the following hours:08:00 to 22:00 Monday to Friday08:00 to 22:00 on Saturdays08:00 to 22:00 on Sundays and bank holidaysReason: To ensure satisfactory living conditions for neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to the commencement of development, details of waste and recycling facilities to serve the development to which this permission relates shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority. The refuse and recycling facilities as shown in the approved details shall be provided prior to beneficial occupation of the development and shall be permanently retained thereafter. The developer and/or their successors in title shall take all reasonable steps to ensure that all refuse and recyclable materials associated with the development are either stored within these facilities or internally within the building(s) on the application site, and that no refuse or recycling material is stored or placed for collection on the public highway except on the day of collection.Reason: These details are required prior to commencement of development because the details would affect the subsequent design of other elements of the scheme and must be agreed at the outset and to ensure proper waste management in the interests of the character and appearance of the area and the living conditions of neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policies 5.17 and 7.4 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS8 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

The proposed development is considered to be in accordance with Schedule 2, Part 3, Class C of the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) Order (England) 2015 (as amended). Therefore, it is recommended that prior approval is granted.

The development to which this decision relates shall be carried out in strict accordance with the following plans/documents:SITE LOCATION PLAN3048/E00 EXTRACT FAN DETAILS3048/E001 -PROPOSED GROUND FLOOR KITCHEN EXTRACT INSTALLATIONWS02-PP-01 -EXISTING AND PROPOSED LAYOUTReason:  For the avoidance of doubt and in the interests of proper planning.

SiteThe application site is a two-storey semi-detached dwellinghouse located on Douglas Road. The site is not subject to any particular designations or environmental constraints.ConsultationsSeven neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and no representations were received.ConsiderationThe key areas of assessment are: The impact of the development on character and appearance. The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.When read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Officers Comments: The application proposes a single storey extension to the front of the dwellinghouse to facilitate a porch. Whilst the proposed porch would extend rather high on the front elevation of the dwellinghouse, almost encroaching on the cill height of the first floor, this matter would not warrant refusal. The proposed development would still appear proportionate and subordinate in relation to the dwellinghouse.  The changes proposed to the fenestration on the side and rear elevations would be in keeping with the property. Overall, it is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.Policy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officers Comments: It is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

SiteThe application site is a three-storey semi-detached dwellinghouse located on Camel Grove. The site is not subject to any particular designations or environmental constraints.Consultations3 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and no representations were received.ConsiderationThe key areas of assessment are: The impact of the development on character and appearance. The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.When read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Officers Comments: The application proposes the construction of a single storey rear extension. Whilst this extension would exceed the maximum recommended height of 3 metres for a flat roof extension (measuring 3.2 metres) and would exceed the recommended maximum depth of 3.5 metres (measuring 4 metres in depth), it would still appear proportionate and subordinate in relation to the dwellinghouse. The proposed development is therefore considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.Policy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officers Comments: It is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

The site comprises a detached dwelling located on the western side of Raeburn Avenue and is not subject to any particular constraints or designations.5 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and 1 objection has been received raising the following summarised concerns: Noise; and,Privacy.Given that the proposal would be for residential use, in a predominantly residential area officers consider that there would be no material increase in noise. Notwithstanding the propsed development's impact upon neighbouring resdiential amenity willl be considered as part of the assessment below:The key areas of assessment are: - The design of the proposed development;- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and,- The impact of the development on highways and transportation matters.DesignWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment:The proposed rear extension is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development. AmenityPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance. Officer Comment: Given that the proposal would not increase the existing footprint of the dwelling, or extend closer to the shared boundaries, it is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance or loss of light. While a rooflight is proposed to the southern roof pitch, to mitigate against any loss of privacy, officers consider that a condition could be imposed in the event of an approval to ensure that the window is obscure glazed and non-opening at 1.7m above finished floor level. The high level window proposed in the northrn elevation would not have any adverse impact as it would be above head height.TransportationPolicy T6 of the London Plan 2021 states that car parking should be restricted in line with levels of existing and future public transport accessibility and connectivity. The maximum standards as set out in policies T6.1 to T6.5 should be applied to development proposals.Policy DM9, Policy DM10 and the Council's Sustainable Transport SPD 2013 together require development proposals to comply with the car parking standards in the London Plan.Officer Comment: Given the existing garage's small dimensions it would not be able to safely accommodate on-site car parking and would not comply with the space parameters required by the Sustainable Transport SPD, 2013. As such, officers consider that the proposal would not result in the loss of off-street car parking provision on site. Furthermore, the hardstanding to the front of the property would provide adequate space for 2 car parking spaces. Whilst this level of provision would be in excess of the maximum standards set out in the London Plan 2021 this issue would not warrant grounds for refusal as it is reflective of the existing situation. Therefore, overall, the proposal is considered not to have an adverse impact upon car parking provision, traffic congestion or highway safety, in compliance with Policy DM9 and DM10.In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

The site comprises a semi-detached dwelling on the western side of Gilders Road.It is not subject to any particular site constraints or policy designations.7 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and no representations have been received. The key areas of assessment are: - The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings. DesignWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: The proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development. AmenityPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance. Officer Comment: Given the modest scale of the proposed development, officers consider that it would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy. In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

The application is made pursuant to Section 96A of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 (as amended), which concerns non-material amendments to planning permission.Under Section 96A, a change may be made to any planning permission, including through the imposition of new conditions or the removal/alteration of existing conditions, if the local planning authority is satisfied that the change is not material. In deciding whether a change is material, a local planning authority must have regard to the effect of the change, together with any previous changes made under this section, on the planning permission as originally granted. The National Planning Practice Guidance states that there is no statutory definition of 'non-material'. This is because it will be dependent on the context of the overall scheme - an amendment that is non-material in one context may be material in another. The judgement on 'materially' in any particular case is one of fact and degree. The application seeks to increase the width of the proposed ground floor rear extension by 600mm. Officers consider that an assessment would have to be made to ensure that the proposed alterations would not give rise to any adverse impacts with regards to loss of light/sunlight or increase in overbearing appearance for the occupiers of neighbouring properties. As such, the proposed changes are considered not to be non-material.

Whether or not a proposed amendment is considered to be non-material will depend on the circumstances of the case. There is no statutory definition of 'non material'. This is because it will be dependant on the context of the overall scheme - what may be non-material in one context may be material in another. Whether or not a change can be considered as a "non-material amendment" may be defined according to established legal concepts of materiality and de minimis. The local planning authority must have regard to the effect of the change, together with any previous changes made under section 96A. The local planning authority does not assess the acceptability of the proposed amendment but its magnitude

The assessment of this application is based on measurements taken from the submitted drawings / plans. If it transpires that the drawings / plans submitted are incorrect this would nullify the validity of this decision and you are advised to submit a fresh application with the correct information / drawings.

The applicant is informed that the submitted details for condition 3 (Materials) of planning permission 21/02219/FUL have been assessed and are hereby approved subject to carrying out the development in accordance with the approved details.

Several submitted drawings show conflicting scale information and some are not showing a scale bar:Examples:Drawing 1 Existing Plans - states scale is 1:100 with a scale bar showing 1:50Drawing 13 Site Location Plan - states scale is 1:200 with a scale bar showing 1:125022/AXIZ V/38BAZALG/01 Proposed Ground Floor Plan - Shows no scale barAll drawings (not just these 3 examples) must be corrected and re-submittedCorrect scale information (without conflict) and a scale bar must be shown on all drawings

Please provide copies of all four existing and proposed elevations at a recognised scale of 1:50 or 1:100, providing a scale bar, showing all elevations not just part and indicating all key dimensions for the proposed work.The submitted documents have only two elevations.

Submitted Drawings: Prop A2 Proposed Ground Floor Plan (Doors and windows are not shown)Prop A3 Proposed First Floor Plan (Doors and Windows are not shown)Prop A4 Proposed Loft Plan (Details of roof materials are not shown)Prop A5 Proposed Roof Plan (Details of roof materials are not shown)Are invalid, as only simple outline has been shown, without details of windows, doors or materials.Please correct and re-submit (these drawings only) asap to avoid any further delay
